body: Also what stream has stream id 0?
It looks like `ConnectionStream` has stream id 0 trying to figure out what that means in context of everything else.

OK, so it looks like that means it's not an error specific to a single stream, but instead an error with the overall connection?

```
     * @return If the {@code id} is not
     * {@link Http2CodecUtil#CONNECTION_STREAM_ID} then a {@link Http2Exception.StreamException} will be returned.
     * Otherwise the error is considered a connection error and a {@link Http2Exception} is returned.
```

Yeah, the request is fully received (half closed) and so doesn't need any flow control. The response follows flow control like normal.

This problem would happen reliably with PUT/POST, but wouldn't be triggered by the GET/OPTIONS that we typically see.

This seems to be a problem with the `InboundHttpToHttp2Adapter` utility: it doesn't work with consumeBytes, but it does correctly [throw away the onDataRead return value](https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/74f24a5/codec-http2/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http2/InboundHttpToHttp2Adapter.java?utf8=%E2%9C%93#L67) which is the simpler form of flow control. Worst-case, I guess we could hack `Http2FrameCodec.consumeBytes` to do nothing when it's the upgrade stream, say, with logic like `streamId == 1 && stream.getProperty(upgradeKey)` (we'd create upgradeKey; it doesn't exist now). Doing it "right" looks pretty ugly; if we leave `InboundHttpToHttp2Adapter` as-is it deserves a warning.

Cool, what do you think the next step should be?  Adding this hack?  And right now the only work-around I can think of is extending Http2MultiplexCodecBuilder . . . anything else I could plausibly do?

I've also found

Which makes it seem like we should be stripping more headers here.  The only valid TE header is "trailers".

Adding the hack sounds good to me. It's quick and easy. We can fix it up better if/when we figure out an alternative.

As far as workarounds... If patching Netty isn't an option, then yeah, extending Http2MultiplexCodecBuilder is probably about the only option.

@normanmaurer I've been busy with shipping something, haven't had a chance to look at this yet, but I'm still happy to add the hack when I have time.  I was able to work around this by extending the bejeezus out of Http2MultiplexCodecBuilder.
@mosesn could you be more specific how did you extend Http2MultiplexCodecBuilder to workaround this issue?  Thanks.

@ximyu sure, I have an open source copy you can take a look at: https://github.com/twitter/finagle/blob/develop/finagle-http2/src/main/scala/io/netty/handler/codec/http2/UpgradeMultiplexCodecBuilder.scala
Ah, I see. Thanks a lot for sending the code snippet.  Having to put this class under package io.netty.handler.codec.http2 is really annoying :)
@mosesn so you think this is also what we should do in netty ?
